I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  While developing Asia has made considerable progress in reducing poverty, far too 
many  Asians  continue to  live  in  poverty.  If  measured  by  a  poverty  line  of  $2 per  day,  a 
staggering  1.8  billion,  or  54%,  of  developing  Asia’s  people  were  poor  in  2005.1  Many 
interventions are important for helping the poor climb out of poverty, but, in the final analysis, 
countries must be able to generate productive and well-paying employment opportunities for 
their workforces. Recognition of this has led to including “full and productive employment and 
decent work for all” as a target for achieving Goal 1 of the Millennium Development Goals (i.e., 
eradication of extreme poverty and hunger).  
 
2.  Analysis  of  labor  force  outcomes  in  the  region  indicates  considerable  weaknesses 
among countries’ track records in generating productive and well-paying jobs. This is true even 
for countries where aggregate indicators of economic performance, such as growth in gross 
domestic product per capita, have been strong. In India, for example, the transition of the labor 
force from low-productivity, low-paying jobs in the rural and urban informal sectors to the more 
productive and better paying formal sector has been exceedingly slow despite an economy that 
has been among the fastest-growing in the world over the last decade. Along similar lines, 
unemployment and underemployment continue to affect about a quarter of the Philippine labor 
force as wages for even the typical full-time worker have barely kept up with inflation.2  
 
3.  What can policymakers in the region do to encourage the growth of good jobs and 
thereby promote inclusive growth? Encouraging employment growth in the public sector is not a 
viable option. Productive and well-paying employment opportunities will have to come from 
private enterprises, especially nonagricultural ones. There is a critical role for public policy, 
however, because the operation and growth of private enterprises is influenced in important 
ways by the policies and strategies adopted by governments to promote industrial development 
and structural transformation. It is in this context that the proposed regional technical assistance 
(TA) seeks to improve our knowledge of how different types of policies and strategies affect 
enterprise growth, especially among small and medium enterprises (SMEs), and the creation of 
productive and well-paying jobs in the developing member countries (DMCs) of the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB).3 The TA design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.4
 
II.  ISSUES 
4.  A feature of nonagricultural employment in many developing countries is that it tends to 
be concentrated among small enterprises. In fact, it is especially concentrated among the very 
small in lower-income developing countries. In both India and the Philippines, for example, the

3  The terms “enterprise,” “firm,” and “establishment” are used interchangeably here. Strictly speaking, they are 
distinct concepts. An establishment is a single physical location at which business is conducted or where services 
or industrial operations are performed. An enterprise or firm is a business organization consisting of one or more 
domestic establishments under common ownership or control. For companies with only one establishment, the 
enterprise and establishment are the same. 
4  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 3 November 2008.

2   
share of total employment in manufacturing accounted for by enterprises with between 5 and 9 
workers was over 20% in the 1980s.  This contrasts markedly with higher income DMCs such 
as  the  Republic  of  Korea,  Malaysia,  Taipei,China,  and  Thailand  where  such  enterprises 
accounted for 10% or less of manufacturing employment. 5
 
5.  The fact that a large fraction of workers is employed in small enterprises is not in and of 
itself a problem. A problem can arise, however, if small enterprises are characterized by very 
low productivity and wages. While it is the case that labor productivity—a key determinant of 
wages—tends to increase everywhere with the size of enterprise, labor productivity of the 
smallest enterprises can be particularly low relative to large enterprises in lower-income DMCs: 
The differential in labor productivity between the smallest and largest enterprises has been 
found to be on the order of 1:8 or greater in the case of India and the Philippines, for example.6 
This can be contrasted with a differential of about 1:3 in several of the other, higher-income 
DMCs. Given the very heterogeneous wage and productivity levels, where it is that jobs are 
being created is a matter of considerable importance.  
 
6.  Under the assumption that it is difficult to improve productivity and earnings of small 
enterprises beyond some relatively low threshold, the foregoing suggests that an expansion of 
good  jobs  would  require  that  a  greater  share  of  employment  be  accounted  for  by  larger 
enterprises.  Conceptually,  two  types  of  processes  underlie  such  an  expansion:  (i) 
transformation of small enterprises into more productive, larger ones; and (ii) growth of larger 
enterprises. 
 
7.  The foregoing discussion raises several important questions: 
(i)  How is employment in Asia distributed across various production sectors and 
enterprises?7 How are labor productivity and/or wages distributed across different 
production sectors and enterprises?  
(ii)  What  explains  the  large  heterogeneity  of  wages  and  productivity  across 
enterprise size groups seen in some countries but not others? What elements of 
the policy environment can explain how firm size is distributed across countries?  
(iii)  What constrains the growth of enterprises, especially SMEs? To what extent are 
particular types of policies and strategies adopted by governments at work? To 
what  extent  are  market  failures  or  factors  having  to  do  with  enterprises 
themselves (such as characteristics of entrepreneurs or of the markets to which 
enterprises  cater)  constraints?  What  types  of  policies  and  strategies  can 
policymakers rely on for promoting enterprise growth? 
(iv)  How does the demand for labor behave in response to the growth of different 
types of enterprises? To what extent is the growth of demand for labor biased in 
favor of skilled workers as enterprises expand and adopt new technologies? 
What types of skills are most valued by firms? What are the roles of general, 
technical, and vocational education in this regard?

8.  Answers to these questions will be important for formulating policies and strategies 
ensuring dynamism among enterprises and the creation of productive and well-paying jobs.  
 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.   Impact and Outcome 
9.  The TA studies are expected to improve our understanding as to what types of economic 
policies and strategies are most effective in encouraging the transition of small, low-productivity 
enterprises into higher-productivity ones and expanding the availability of productive and well-
paying jobs. More specifically, the TA studies are expected to influence the design of policies 
and strategies used to promote SMEs along with education and skills-development initiatives so 
that these are geared toward the goal of significantly increasing employment prospects and 
earnings of the typical worker. 
 
B.   Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The  TA  will  address  the  questions  listed  in  para.  7  through  research  studies 
implemented in two phases. Phase 1 will consist of a relatively broad-based analysis of the TA 
issues using publicly available information on enterprises and a stock-taking of the recent 
literature on constraints to the growth of enterprises. Output from Phase 1 will be utilized in 
ADB’s Key Indicators 2009 for a special chapter on enterprises in Asia. Phase 2 will consist of 
in-depth studies of three DMCs: India, Indonesia, and the Philippines. An in-depth country study 
of similar scope, focusing on Pakistan, will be financed and implemented by ADB’s Central and 
West Asia Department (CWRD).8 Some analysis will also be carried out on enterprises in the 
People’s Republic of China (PRC). Given the considerable success of the PRC’s manufacturing 
and even services sectors in expanding production, it will be useful to examine how different 
types of enterprises have performed and to understand the implications of enterprise growth for 
the employment and wages of PRC workers. Examining the PRC experience can provide useful 
lessons for public policy in other DMCs. 
 
1.  Phase 1: Broad-Based Analysis 
 
11.  Phase 1 will run from January 2009 through July 2009 and consist of several activities. A 
first activity will be to generate a report consisting of metadata (i.e., data about data) on 
enterprise statistics across 13 DMCs.9 The report will provide descriptions of what types of 
enterprise statistics are collected, what methods are used in data collection, comparability of 
statistics across the DMCs, and the types of data made available for public access (e.g., 
whether panel data on establishments is available). A second activity will be to develop a 
database on the distribution of employment and such other important economic variables as 
value  added,  labor  productivity,  and  wages  according  to  enterprise  size  across  different 
production sectors for the 13 DMCs. The database will rely on official publications of national 
statistics offices.10 A final activity will be to generate an analytical report. In addition to using the

2.  Phase 2: In-Depth Country Studies in India, Indonesia, and the Philippines11 
 
12.  The studies will undertake detailed country-specific analysis of what explains enterprise 
size and its distribution, the factors constraining the growth of SMEs, the types of policies and 
strategies that can alleviate these constraints, and how the demand for labor may be expected 
to respond to enterprise growth (along with implications for labor earnings). The focus will be on 
the manufacturing and services sectors. 
 
13.  A specific program of research for each country study will be developed in consultation 
with relevant national agencies and international and national experts on industrial development 
and SME issues (including experts at ADB). The consultation process will be facilitated by the 
preparation  during  January–May  2009  of  country-specific  stock-taking  studies,12  detailed 
metadata  on  enterprise  statistics,  and  a  detailed  review  of  recent  international  literature. 
Inception workshops will be held in each of the countries around June 2009. Country-specific 
programs of research will be finalized at latest by September 2009.  
 
14.  The country studies will examine the issues noted above through (i) rigorous analysis of 
enterprise data from existing industrial censuses and/or nationally representative surveys, (ii) 
follow-up analysis based on primary surveys of enterprises and workers or evaluation of an 
existing program aimed at promoting enterprises and/or entrepreneurship, and (iii) qualitative 
case studies based on key informant interviews and focus group discussions. 
 
15.  A number of issues raised by recent literature will be important to consider in developing 
the  country  studies,  including  (among  others)  the  role  of  entrepreneurship,  limitations  of 
enterprise surveys in ascertaining constraints to growth of enterprises (and especially those 
stemming from market failures), and challenges in measuring skills. Appendix 2 describes these 
issues in detail, along with some possible approaches that could be used. It will be important to 
fully flesh out these approaches before implementing the studies (i.e., prior to October 2009).  
 
C.   Cost and Financing 
16.  The TA is estimated to cost $500,000. It will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
technical assistance funding program and cover consulting services; training and workshops; 
data collection, assessment, and analysis; equipment; and administrative and support costs. 
Detailed cost estimates are in Appendix 3.

D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  ADB  will  be  the  Executing  Agency  for  the  TA,  which  will  be  administered  by  the 
Economics and Research Department. Confirmation of no-objection will be obtained from the 
government of each DMC participating in phase 2 (PRC, India, Indonesia, and the Philippines) 
prior to starting TA activities, in coordination with their regional departments.  
 
18.  The TA will be implemented from January 2009 to July 2011 and finance 41 person-
months of consulting services: 6 international and 35 national. Consultants will be selected and 
engaged individually by ADB in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, 
as amended from time to time). The TA will also finance survey work in selected DMCs. A 
national institution will be engaged through consultant qualification selection for the survey work 
in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants. The choice of consultant 
qualification selection stems from the relatively small budget for the survey work (less than 
$100,000 per survey) and the straightforward nature of the survey work. The terms of reference

19.  ADB  will  procure  computer  hardware,  software,  data  entry  devices,  and  technical 
manuals in accordance with its Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to time), 
and this equipment will be disposed of in accordance with instructions on administering grant-
financed technical assistance.13

8   Appendix 2 
 
ANALYTICAL AND METHODOLOGICAL ISSUES RAISED BY  
RECENT LITERATURE ON ENTERPRISE SIZE AND GROWTH 
 
 
1.  A number of issues raised by recent literature will be important to consider in developing 
the in-depth country studies of phase 2. First, the analysis of enterprise size and its distribution 
should be sensitive to the economics literature on the determinants of firm size. It should show a 
clear understanding as to the limits of the available data and empirical framework used in 
distinguishing between competing explanations.1   
 
2.  Second, a number of recent studies have questioned whether small and medium-sized 
enterprises (SMEs)—and especially the smaller enterprises among them and those operating in 
the informal sector—can be engines of growth. For example, Del Mel, McKenzie, and Woodruff  
compare the characteristics of own-account workers in Sri Lanka with owners of larger firms.2 
Their findings suggest that, for the most part, own-account workers are more like wageworkers 
than owners of larger firms, and they are unlikely to expand and become employers. Similarly, 
La Porta and Shleifer use information from the World Bank’s enterprise surveys carried out in 
nearly 100 countries and find that virtually none of the formal enterprises have ever been 
informal, strongly suggesting that the typical informal and/or small enterprise is very unlikely to 
graduate into a larger, formal enterprise.3 It is important to examine these findings more closely 
in the context of specific countries. If it is true that small enterprises are unlikely to deliver in 
generating good jobs, then the focus of policy may have to be on understanding the constraints 
to growth among larger enterprises and relieving these.  
 
3.  Third, determining the key constraints to growth of enterprises is not straightforward. 
Conceptually, it is useful to think about constraints as stemming from two types of failures: 
government failures and market failures. Government failures are typically considered to result 
from (among others) regulatory barriers to entry, exit, and competition; poor provision of public 
infrastructure  inputs;  and  weak  mechanisms  for  contract  enforcement.  Market  failures  are 
likewise believed to stem from various sources, including credit market imperfections, learning 
externalities, and coordination failures. Much of the recent empirical work has focused on 
examining the role of government failures, and, insofar as market failures are concerned, the 
emphasis has been on credit market imperfections. Less attention seems to have been paid to 
evaluating the impacts of learning externalities and coordination failures.4 Given that market 
failures stemming from the latter might be particularly critical for entrepreneurs contemplating 
more efficient (but perhaps riskier) production methods or production of nontraditional products, 
the omission seems to be a serious one. Careful consideration will need to be given to empirical 
approaches that can capture both government and market failures in a more balanced way.

4.  Fourth, an increasingly popular tool used in the analysis of constraints to growth of 
enterprises has been to conduct surveys of enterprise managers. Though no doubt useful—and 
some enterprise surveys are expected to be conducted in this project—it is important to bear in 
mind some limitations of this approach: (i) the analysis of responses from existing surveys may 
be subject to survivor bias,5 and (ii) the role of market failures (as opposed to government 
failures) may be particularly difficult to tease out from enterprise surveys. This is especially so if 
the most serious market failures stem from learning externalities or coordination failures. For 
example, enterprises involved in agro-processing might grow rapidly if a cold storage logistics 
system were developed but not until then. A generic enterprise survey would be unlikely to 
uncover this market failure constraining growth. 
 
5.  Fifth, the fact that virtually all governments have in place a variety of programs and 
interventions for promoting SMEs suggests that an impact-evaluation-type study holds promise. 
Of course, the set of programs and interventions actually being undertaken would clearly limit 
what could be studied (as well as the willingness of the agency administering the program or 
intervention to collaborate in an impact evaluation). Ideally, the impact evaluation would be able 
to consider not only interventions aimed at improving access to finance and/or provision of 
finance  at  subsidized  rates  (which  seem  to  be  the  most  common  interventions)  but  also 
interventions  aimed  at  alleviating  market  failures  related  to  learning  and/or  coordination 
externalities (and perhaps interventions that remove legal and regulatory constraints that may 
be affecting SME development). 
 
6.  Sixth, the process of structural transformation also affects the composition of the labor 
force. In particular, we see a significant increase in the participation of women in the labor force 
as a country becomes more industrialized. In the context of firm size, there are no a priori 
theories  predicting  the  connection  between  firm  size  and  female  labor  force  participation. 
However, empirical evidence suggests that a larger share of female workers within an industry 
is associated with lower average wages. As far as the data will allow, we will analyze whether 
any  linkages  can  be  statistically  discerned  between  the  development  of  enterprises,  the 
employment of women workers, and the evolution of wages. 
 
7.  Finally, the analysis of the employment-related implications of enterprise growth, and 
especially the relationship between production technologies and skills required of workers, will 
require a search for innovative approaches. For example, while many studies have examined 
the demand for skilled versus unskilled labor in the context of globalization, there are several 
methodological issues that prevent firm conclusions from being drawn. In the first place, the 
definition of skills remains essentially a black box; researchers are forced to rely on using either 
educational attainment of workers or their classification as production or nonproduction workers 
as proxy measures for skills. Neither approach is particularly satisfactory. The situation appears 
to be even worse for technology. In particular, available data sets on enterprises provide very 
little by way of distinguishing whether the production process being used is modern versus 
traditional (or otherwise for characterizing the technology involved). It may be the case that the 
analysis of employment issues will have to rely more on qualitative case studies conducted 
using interviews with key informants. 
 
                                                 
5  In a nutshell, the problem is that, by relying on responses from existing enterprises, we may be drawing inferences 
on what is or is not a constraint using responses from enterprises that were able to tackle problems which may be 
preventing others from investing and setting up shop in the first place or from surviving in case they had entered 
the market.

10   Appendix 2 
 
8.  Clearly, some of the issues raised above may not be easy to resolve. Nevertheless, 
there are approaches that hold promise. First, enterprise-level data with geographic markers 
can be used alongside information on location-specific characteristics (such as proximity to 
major markets or to other producers, average demographic characteristics of workers, banking 
facilities, road networks, and indicators of local regulations and institutions) to examine how the 
availability  or  presence  of  various  factors  influences  the  size  distribution  and  growth  of 
enterprises, employment, and wages. Similarly, information on the particular industrial goods 
being produced by enterprises can be used along the lines of Rajan and Zingales, whereby 
variations  in  the  pattern  of  enterprise  growth  across  relevant  industrial  characteristics  and 
geographic locations is used to infer the factors constraining enterprise growth.6,7 Finally, follow-
up analysis based on retrospective interviews of previously surveyed enterprises presents a 
useful  way  for  dealing  with  the  survivor  bias  involved  in  interviewing  currently  existing 
enterprises only. Of course, it will be important to fully flesh out these approaches prior to 
implementing the studies.  
 
                                                 
6  Raghuram G. Rajan and Luigi Zingales (1998. Financial dependence and growth. American Economic Review 
88(3): 559–86) use data from the United States to categorize industries in terms of whether or not they are 
dependent on external finance. They then examine whether such industries are more or less likely to emerge in 
other countries. They find that industries especially dependent on external finance develop more slowly in countries 
with weak financial markets, indicating that finance may be a binding constraint to growth, but more so in particular 
industries than others. This approach has recently been used by Poonam Gupta, Rana Hasan, and Utsav Kumar 
(forthcoming. Big Reforms but Small Payoffs: Explaining the Weak Record of Growth in Indian Manufacturing. New 
Delhi: India Policy Forum.) to determine whether state level measures of infrastructure provision, labor regulation, 
and financial development influence patterns of industrial development in India. 
7  The interplay between enterprise dynamics and geographical location seem particularly important to study. John S. 
Felkner  and  Robert  M.  Townsend  (2007.  Enterprise  and  wealth  of  villages.  Available: 
http://cier.uchicago.edu/papers/2006/felkner_townsend_2006.pdf), for example, show how geography and space 
importantly influence occupational shifts and movements into entrepreneurship in Thailand.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  International Consultant: Economist or Statistician—Metadata and Database on 
Enterprise Statistics (2 person-months) 
1.  The  consultant  will  be  an  economist  or  statistician  with  excellent  knowledge  about 
enterprise  statistics.  The  consultant  will  prepare  metadata  on  enterprise  statistics  and  a 
database on production- and employment-related statistics for enterprises in 13 developing 
member  countries  (DMCs)  using  publications  of  national  statistics  offices  and  international 
databases  such  as  the  United  Nations  Industrial  Development  Organization’s  Industrial 
Statistics database and the International Labour Organization’s Key Indicators of the Labor 
Market database. The DMCs are Bangladesh, People’s Republic of China, Fiji Islands, India, 
Indonesia, Republic of Korea, Malaysia, Nepal, Pakistan, Philippines, Taipei,China, Thailand, 
and Viet Nam.  
 
2.  The main information that will need to be collected includes: 
(i)  Metadata  on  enterprise  statistics.  Basic  information  on  enterprise  statistics 
across 13 DMCs will be provided using publications of national statistics offices. 
(ii)  Tabulated  data  on  the  distribution  of  economic  data  by  enterprise  and/or 
establishment  size.  Tabulations  are  required  for  distribution  of  employment, 
output,  value  added,  wage  bill,  fixed  assets,  and  number  of  enterprises  by 
enterprise size groups. To the extent possible, the tabulations should be provided 
by major production sector (agriculture, industry, manufacturing subsector, and 
services) and by formal and informal sectors. If possible, tabulations should also 
be  provided  separately  by  ownership  structure  (for  example,  private  sector 
versus public sector). Tabulations are required for the latest year available as 
well as for earlier years spaced approximately 10 years apart. The consultant will 
need to take considerable care in documenting the comparability of statistics 
across countries. In particular, attention will need to be given to the definitions 
and coverage of the underlying enterprise statistics across countries. 
(iii)  Basic output and employment statistics for industries classified at the one-digit 
industry  level  (for  example,  divisions  A–J  in  terms  of  Standard  Industrial 
Classification) for the latest year available as well as for earlier years spaced 
approximately 10 years apart. 
 
3.  Outputs: report on metadata and database (February 2009). 
 
B.  International Consultant: Economist—Analysis of Size Distribution and 
Constraints to Enterprise Growth (1 person-month, intermittent) 
4.  The  consultant  should  have  a  strong  background  in  development  economics  and 
extensive experience working on industrial development issues, especially with reference to 
Asian economies. The main task of the consultant will be to prepare a report that analyzes the 
size distribution of enterprises across Asian economies, the factors that constrain the growth of 
enterprises (especially small and medium-sized ones), and the links between enterprise growth 
and employment creation. The contents of the report will serve as inputs to a special chapter on 
enterprises in Asia for the Asian Development Bank (ADB) Key Indicators 2009 publication. 
 
5.  The consultant’s report will: 
(i)  Describe the size distribution of enterprises in developing Asian countries. The 
report will utilize tabulated distribution data on enterprises (to be provided by

Appendix 4        13 
ADB staff) to examine how employment, value added, wage bill, fixed assets, 
and  labor  productivity  are  distributed  across  enterprise  size  groups  (where 
enterprise  size  is  measured  in  terms  of  number  of  workers)  and  by  major 
production sectors. The analysis will reveal whether, and in which countries, the 
size distribution of enterprises is characterized by (a) strong concentration of 
workers in small firms, (b) large differentials in labor productivity and/or wages by 
enterprise  size,  and  (c)  a  “missing  middle”  whereby  much  employment  is 
accounted  for  by  small  and  large  enterprises.  Further,  the  analysis  should 
describe whether a size distribution characterized by a missing middle has any 
special consequences for economic performance.  
(ii)  Explain  the  policy  and  institutional  factors  that  may  be  influencing  size 
distributions  and  their  evolution.  The  report  will  discuss  various  policy  and 
institutional factors that may explain the patterns of size distributions seen across 
DMCs and the changes in size distributions over time. The types of policy and 
institutional  factors  should  be  guided  by  existing  literature  and  country 
experiences. Examples would include the stance of trade policy, industrial policy 
(encompassing  policies  and  strategies  adopted  by  governments  to  foster 
industrial  development  and  technological  capabilities),  business  regulations, 
labor regulations, credit market imperfections, as well as education and training 
policies.  
(iii)  Relate the size distribution of enterprises to constraints on small enterprises. The 
report  will  draw  upon  existing  literature  to  explain  why  some  economies  in 
developing Asia seem to have been successful in having dynamic small-scale 
sectors (i.e., small enterprises that are able to generate relatively high earnings 
for their employees and/or small enterprises that are able to grow into larger 
enterprises). The reports will provide lessons from the success stories for those 
countries with lagging small-scale sectors. 
(iv)  Examine the employment-related implications of enterprise growth. It will address 
the  following  questions:  Which  production  sectors  and  types  of  firms  are 
generating reasonably well-paying jobs? What factors can explain the patterns 
we see? To what extent is the growth of demand for labor biased in favor of 
skilled workers as enterprises expand and adopt new technologies? What are the 
types of skills that are being most valued by firms? What are the roles of general, 
technical, and vocational education in this regard? 
 
6.  Outputs: (i) outline of report (finalized after discussions with ADB staff, early-January 
2009), (ii) draft report (mid-February 2009), and (iii) final report (mid-March 2009). 
 
 
C.  National Consultants: Economists or Statisticians—Detailed Metadata on 
Enterprise- and Employment-Related Statistics (1 person-month each for 3 DMCs, 
intermittent) 
7.  The  consultant  will  be  an  expert  on  enterprise-  and  employment-related  statistics 
collected by both the national statistics office as well as administrative agencies, as applicable 
(for example, data collected by ministries of industry, commerce, trade, labor). The task of the 
consultant will be to prepare a report containing metadata on enterprise- and employment-
related statistics.

8.  The metadata will describe: 
(i)  Key definitions pertaining to enterprises (including definitions of establishments, 
enterprises, and firms) used by the national statistical system of the country. 
(ii)  The system in place among national statistics offices and relevant administrative 
agencies  for  collecting  enterprise  statistics  for  different  types  of  enterprises 
(including formal and informal sector enterprises; public and private enterprises; 
small, medium, and large enterprises) and wages and/or earnings1 for different 
types of workers. 
(iii)  The types of surveys and censuses carried out for collecting enterprise statistics, 
as well as for employment and wages and/or earnings statistics; how often these 
are collected; and public dissemination policies regarding data. 
(iv)  Reliability of population frames and business registers upon which surveys and 
censuses are based.  
(v)  Ability of business registers or statistical systems accurately to capture formation 
and dissolution of enterprises; ability of statistical systems to track migration of 
workers. 
(vi)  Availability of panel data on enterprises, workers, and matching enterprise and 
worker survey data. 
(vii)  Weaknesses in the systems for collecting enterprise statistics, as well as data on 
employment and wages and/or earnings. Priority areas for improvement should 
be described. (The discussion will focus on variables that are important for policy 
purposes and where quality of data collected needs to be improved—such as 
value  added  for  small  enterprises,  earnings  information  for  self-employed 
workers.)  
 
9.  Output: report on metadata (May 2009).  
 
D.  National Consultants: Economists—Stock-Taking Report on Enterprise 
Development and Generation of Good Jobs (2 person-months each for 4 DMCs, 
intermittent) 
 
10.  The consultant should have a strong background in industrial and/or labor economics 
plus extensive experience working on issues of industrial development and SMEs. The main 
task of the consultant will be to prepare a report that takes stock of trends and policy issues 
relating to enterprise development and the generation of productive and well-paying jobs. The 
report will serve as a key input for developing a program of research for an in-depth study on 
the TA issues. Information from the report is also expected to be an input to a special chapter 
on enterprises in Asia for ADB’s Key Indicators 2009 publication. 
 
11.  The report will:  
(i)  Describe recent trends in enterprise growth and the evolution of employment and 
wages for different types of enterprises and across the major production sectors. 
Documentation  of  entry  and  exit  and  the  life  spans  of  different  types  of 
enterprises will be useful. 
(ii)  Discuss the policy and institutional factors that are believed to drive these trends. 
The  relevant  elements  of  these  factors  would  include  (among  others)  trade

policy,  industrial  policy  (encompassing  policies  and  strategies  adopted  by

and/or entrepreneurship. Finally, he or she will assist in developing issues for analysis through 
qualitative case studies.
